Text Overlay Card The different sized Sheets have two manifestations depending on the viewport width.
Upto the S breakpoint, the paddings and Button sizes are reduced to fit the smaller
Theatre space better. Starting from the M breakpoint, the paddings and Button sizes are
adjusted for the larger screens. The Sheets automatically switch to a bottom Sheet at
Toast the S breakpoint, but this behaviour can be overwritten when needed.

Small Sheet. Medium Sheet. Large Sheet.
Side Sheet alignment
Side Sheets can be aligned to either side of the screen. Right Sheets are our typical
alignment choice, but you may find cases where the alignment should correlate to the
natural position of an action.
x x
Right Sheet. Left Sheet.
Bottom Sheet
The bottom Sheet is reserved for screens below the S breakpoint. It can be set to a full-
screen or to hug its content. For mobile native guidelines on bottom Sheets, look here.
x
x
Bottom Sheet adjusted to cover the entire screen. Bottom Sheet that adjusts to the content.
Sheet header
The title and the back Button are optional, but the Sheet should always have a close
Button. Sometimes certain flows in sheets require multiple steps - a back Button allows
the user to return to a previous stage in such cases. The floating variant is a good
match with content such as images to provide a wider viewport (see Theatre for
examples). However, the transparent headers do not support titles. Also, all header
variants adjust paddings for the S breakpoint to save space.
Modal Header

Floating Modal
Header X

Sheet action footer
The action footer for Sheet is available in single or double actions, stacked or side-by-
side. The side-by-side variant is dedicated for implementations on large-screen (M and
up) viewports with more space for the copy to fit. On the S breakpoint, we stack the
actions instead as the space there is often more limited; the Button size variant also
changes from small to medium.
The action footer variants with Buttons aligned to the left or right are reserved for all
large sheets and medium sheets with only one action. Depending on your use case, you
can adjust which button comes first, primary or secondary. We would advise keeping
the alignment consistent - horizontal alignment has the primary button on the right,
whereas vertical alignment has the primary at the bottom (unless it is a "cancel" action).
If the Sheet contains long content, you can enable an optional Divider to visually
separate the content from the actions.

Backdrop
The backdrop is not part of the component in Figma, however the coded
implementations do include it. Examples and instructions on how to make the backdrop
are provided on Modal Figma page. Please note that there are visual differences
between platforms on how dark and opaque the 'dim' appears.
Behaviour
Sheets are fragile in comparison to a regular page as their temporary nature makes
them easy to dismiss. For this reason, no Sheet should ever contain complex or high-
stakes tasks that could risk a user's information being easily dismissed and lost. See the
Modal containers page, sub-section Modal behaviours, for more details.
The Sheet is best used for focused tasks, providing additional information, and then
returning to the main screen. Sheet Modal provides the space for further details while
staying in the context of the overall user flow. Use it when you need to add more
information without disturbing the path your user is on. It's meant for additional
information you can continue without - essential or critical tasks should not be in a
Sheet but in the main flow.

When choosing Modals it's important to consider that the content or the task you are
presenting never strays too far from the context below. Any content that keeps the
users in a Modal state for a long time runs the risk of distancing them from their
current workflow. This often leads to confusion about where they are, as Modal content
is isolated from an application's familiar navigation elements.
Content that's suitable:
Short, contained tasks. Tasks that have a direct effect to the content below, which can
be achieved in a few small, simple steps.
Additional information. Focused display of related information that may have been
cumbersome to include inline on the page below.
Content to avoid:
Tasks with long, complex or high stake flows.
The temporary nature of Modals means that they can be dismissed easily, either
through the Esc key, or the browser back button. In most cases, any input or progress a
user has made in the Modal will also be lost. Data loss through Modal dismissal should
be low-risk and low-effort to replicate.
Rich content with deep information structures.
These often require their own navigation framework, as it may lead the user too far
down a rabbit hole from which they may not be able to find their way back. Modal
content is typically not part of the root application information architecture.
Content that is intended to be linked directly to.
Modals are an extension of the information on the page they were launched from and
should always require that context to be set first. Direct URLs to Modals may not always
exist, depending on the platform and implementation.

Text line length
We recommend a maximum of 70 characters per line for latin-based languages and 30
characters per line for Chinese, Japanese or Korean-based languages.
This helps to increase readability, especially for people with some reading or vision
disabilities. Long lines of text can become a significant barrier, and they may have
trouble keeping their place and following the flow of text. Having a narrow block of text
makes it easier to continue to the following line.

Resizable Sheet header
A resizable Sheet expands when the user scrolls its contents or
drag the grabber, which is a small horizontal indicator that can
appear at the top edge of a Sheet. Sheets resize according to
their detents, which are heights at which a sheet naturally rests.
Resizable sheet is only available natively for iOS 15 and above.
However custom implementations or 3rd party libraries are
allowed, it's important to adhere to the Apple human interface
Android
In native Android, Sheet has one bottom-aligned variant of the
u— component. Sheet provides more content space than the Prompt
